bioprojects.title: Drechmeria coniospora strain:ARSEF 6962 Genome sequencing and assembly

description.comment: The ascomycete Drechmeria coniospora is the sole formally recognized species in the Drechmeria genus, and is one of the most common and best documented endoparasitoid nematophagous fungus. It infects a variety of nematode species, including plant pathogens such as Aphelenchoides fragariae, Ditylenchus destructor, the root-knot parasitic nematode Meloidogyne spp., and the free-living soil nematode Caenorhabditis elegans. D. coniospora infection induces the expression of a large number of genes encoding antimicrobial peptides in C. elegans, and the infection complex has served as a model to examine innate immunity.

bioprojects.title: Saccharomyces kudriavzevii CR85

description.comment: The ability of the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae to convert glucose, even in the presence of oxygen, via glycolysis and the fermentative pathway to ethanol has played an important role in its domestication. Despite the extensive knowledge on these pathways in S. cerevisiae, relatively little is known about these pathways in other industrially-relevant Saccharomyces yeast species. In this study we explore the diversity of the glycolytic and fermentative pathways within the Saccharomyces genus using S. cerevisiae, S. kudriavzevii and S. eubayanus as paradigms. Sequencing data revealed a highly conserved genetic makeup of the glycolytic and fermentative pathways in the three species in terms of number of paralogous genes. Although promoter regions were less conserved between the three species as compared to coding sequences, binding sites for Rap1, Gcr1 and Abf1, main transcriptional regulators of glycolytic and fermentative genes, were highly conserved. Transcriptome profiling of these three strains grown in aerobic batch cultivation in chemically defined medium with glucose as carbon source, revealed a remarkably similar expression of the glycolytic and fermentative genes across species, and the conserved classification of genes into major and minor paralogs. Furthermore, transplantation of the promoters of major paralogs of S. kudriavzevii and S. eubayanus into S. cerevisiae demonstrated not only the transferability of these promoters, but also the similarity of their strength and response to various environmental stimuli. The relatively low homology of S. kudriavzevii and S. eubayanus promoters to their S. cerevisiae relatives makes them very attractive alternatives for strain construction in S. cerevisiae, thereby expanding S. cerevisiae molecular toolbox.
description.title: Microbe sample from Saccharomyces kudriavzevii

bioprojects.title: Nanopore sequencing and comparative genome analysis confirm lager-brewing yeasts originated from a single hybridization

description.comment: The lager brewing yeast S. pastorianus is a hybrid between S. cerevisiae and S. eubayanus with extensive chromosome aneuploidy. S. pastorianus is subdivided into Group 1 and Group 2 strains: Group 2 strains have higher copy number and a larger degree of heterozygosity for S. cerevisiae chromosomes. As a result, Group 2 strains were hypothesized to have emerged from a hybridization event distinct from Group 1 strains. Current genome assemblies of S. pastorianus strains are incomplete and highly fragmented, limiting our ability to investigate their evolutionary history. To fill this gap, we generated a chromosome-level genome assembly of the S. pastorianus strain CBS 1483 using MinION sequencing and analysed the newly assembled subtelomeric regions and chromosome heterozygosity. To analyse the evolutionary history of S. pastorianus strains, we developed Alpaca: a method to compute sequence similarity between genomes without assuming linear evolution. Alpaca revealed high similarities between the S. cerevisiae subgenomes of Group 1 and 2 strains, and marked differences from sequenced S. cerevisiae strains. Our findings suggest that Group 1 and Group 2 strains originated from a single hybridization involving a heterozygous S. cerevisiae strain, followed by loss of S. cerevisiae genome content in Group 1 strains. The clear differences between both groups may originate from dissemination from few initial isolates. Furthermore, Alpaca provides a computationally inexpensive method to analyse evolutionary relationships while considering non-linear evolution such as horizontal gene transfer and sexual reproduction, providing a complementary viewpoint beyond traditional phylogenetic approaches.
description.title: Microbe sample from Saccharomyces pastorianus CBS1483

bioprojects.title: Sequencing and comparative genomics of Sporisorium reilianum f. sp. reilianum strain SRS1_H2-8

description.comment: Sporisorium reilianum f. sp. reilianum causes head smut on sorghum and has only very limited capacity to cause head smut on maize. Genome sequencing of the strain SRS1_H2-8 and comparison of its genome to the genome of the maize head smut fungus Sporisorium reilianum f. sp. zeae might reveal components of host adaptation of Sporisorium reilianum.

description.comment: Ustilago bromivora is a biotrophic pathogenic fungus belonging to the group of head smuts. It infects the model grass Brachypodium distachyon and causes visible symptoms in the late stages of the plant development were infected spikelets are converted to smut sori. The well-established model smut fungus Ustilago maydis has been previously shown to be a useful to study aspects of biotrophic pathogenic fungi in general.

bioprojects.title: Candida hispaniensis strain CBS 9996 genome sequence

description.comment: The genome of Candida hispaniensis strain CBS 9996 has been sequenced using 454 technology. The assembly was made with Celera assembler and resulted in 7 scaffolds larger than 5 kb with a coverage of 39.46X. The rDNA cluster was assembled independently and manually integrated between scaffolds harboring partial rDNA units at one of their extremities. The final assembly relies on 6 scaffolds, one per chromosome, for a total size of 10,652,573 bp and a G+C content of ca 41.6%.
description.title: Candida hispaniensis CBS 9996 genome assembly
